original: Cederwall, Knut Harald, musikdirektör, kompositör, Norrköping, f. 27/ 10/95 i Strövelstorp, Krist. 1., av organist H. J. C. o. Augusta Nilsson. G. 24 m. organist. Ingrid Ek. Barn: GuniMa f. 30. — Realex. i Hälsingborg 12, organist- o. kyrkosång :ex. 15, organist- o. musiklär :ex. v. musikkons. 19, specrstud. i sång 18-19, stud. kontrap. 17-18 o. 19-20, orgelspeln.* o. kördirig. f. thomaskantorn, prof. Günther Ramin i Leipzig 37 o. 38, komp. f. prof. J. N. David där 39. Res. t. Tyskl. 34, Finl. o. Norge 35, Danm. 36, Tyskl. o. Tjeckoslov. 37, Tyskl. o. Holl. 38, Tyskl., Schv^eiz o. Ital. 39. Vik. organist i Harplinge 17, Kropp 18-19, Vadstena 20, sånglär. v. Hälsingborgs nya elemilärov. f. fl 20-21, vik. sånglär. v. folksk. där 21, musiklär. v. Norrköp. h. a. 1. sed. 21, organist i S:t Olai kyrka i Norrköp. sed. 23. Dirig. f. manskören Lyran i Hälsingborg 21, Orfeus i Norrköp. 21-24, led. f. S:t Olai kyrkokör sed. 25, förste dirig. i Linköp. stifts kyrkosångsförb. samt led. av Sv. kyrkosångsförb. centriråd 24-34, Musik. akad. censor v. organistex. sed. 31. Komp.: Tem-pelriddarkantat f. barytonsolo, manskör, orged o. piano, Kantat t. 6 nov. 1932 f. soloröster, bl. kör o. orgel, Kantat t. S :t Olai kyrkas 175-årsjub. f. bl. kör, sopransolo o. orgel, Victima caritates tandem victoria caritates f. deiklam., kör, orgel, sitråik:ar o. träbi :à:rü-str., orgel- o. pianoisitycken, sånger t. oirgel O’. piianOi, kyrkl. körer o. motettier, sitycken f. maniskör o. bl. Ikör m. m. Skr.: airt. o. rec. i tidn. o. tid skr. samt samil :verk. P. A. Bergs jeton.
translated: Cederwall, Knut Harald, music director, composer, from Norrköping, born on October 27th, 1895 in Strövelstorp, Kristianstad county, son of organist H.J.C. and Augusta Nilsson. Married on August 24th, with organist Ingrid Ek, and they have a daughter named Gunima born in 1930. He completed his Realexamen in Hälsingborg in 1912, and graduated with a degree in organ and church singing in 1915. He also completed his studies in music theory, vocal training, and counterpoint, and undertook specialist studies in singing in 1918-1919. He went on study tours to Germany in 1934, Finland and Norway in 1935, Denmark in 1936, Czechoslovakia and Germany in 1937, and Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in 1939. He worked as a temporary organist in Harplinge in 1917, Kropp 1918-1919, and Vadstena in 1920, then as a singing teacher in new elementary school in Hälsingborg from 1920-1921, as a temporary singing teacher in public schools there from 1921, and as a music teacher in Norrköping high school since 1921. He became an organist at St. Olai Church in Norrköping in 1923 and has been a member of the St. Olai church choir since 1925. He was also the first conductor in the Linköping Diocese Church Choir Association and a member of the Swedish Church Choir Association Central Council from 1924-1934. He served as a Music Academy Examiner for organists since 1931. His compositions include the Temple Knight Cantata for baritone solo, male choir, organ, and piano; the Cantata for November 6th, 1932 for solo voices, choir, and organ; the Cantata for St. Olai Church's 175th anniversary for choir, soprano solo, and organ; Victima caritates tandem victoria caritates for declamation, choir, organ, string instruments, and woodwinds; organ and piano pieces, songs for organ and piano, church choirs, and motets for male and mixed choirs, among others. He has written articles and reviews for newspapers and periodicals as well as collected works, including P. A. Berg's medal.
